author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Neither this package nor the ImageAnnotator.jl has documentation at all?

[noblock]

Your `new package` pull request met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have read the package naming guidelines: https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment. You can edit blocking comments, adding `[noblock]` to them in order to unblock auto-merging.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

> Neither this package nor the ImageAnnotator.jl has documentation at all?

This package has a bit in the README - really all there is to know at this point.

On the contrary, there are tests - which also aim at being readable.

[noblock]

To be honest, though, the packages in [your organization](https://github.com/IHPSystems) all severely lack documentation. Packages in General are intended to be useful to the wider community, and without documentation, I don't see how they could be.

This looks much more like a collection of packages that are useful only within the IHP Systems company, which [the guidelines](https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General#do-i-need-to-register-a-package-to-install-it) suggest might be better served by using a [LocalRegistry](https://github.com/GunnarFarneback/LocalRegistry.jl).

Of course, if you do want to add the documentation to put these packages in a broader context, it would be great to have them in the General registry!

[noblock]

Thanks for reviewing, @Moelf and @goerz! And for guarding the General registry - it is highly appreciated.

It is true that we have spent almost no effort on documentation of the [IHP Systems](https://github.com/IHPSystems) packages - the intent is to change that going forward.

The aim of these packages is to provide generally applicable software - with documentation.

Despite the lack of documentation, there is interest in this work outside IHP Systems - in this specific package, at least, cf. [discussion on Slack](https://julialang.slack.com/archives/CB1R90P8R/p1691077744137369) with @ashwani-rathee (in #image-processing).

[noblock]

I am not a great example to use around here or reference ü§£, I made similiar mistake which was rightfully pointed out by @goerz. BTW @stemann I would have wanted to discuss the possibility of using package like this as a package extension rather than a package in itself but ofcourse it's your package and your decision on this.

[noblock]

> BTW @stemann I would have wanted to discuss the possibility of using package like this as a package extension rather than a package in itself but ofcourse it's your package and your decision on this.

Interesting. Please elaborate - but maybe consider separating that discussion into an issue in https://github.com/IHPSystems/ONNXRuntimeImageAnnotators.jl - or a thread on Discourse or Slack...

[noblock]

> It is true that we have spent almost no effort on documentation of the [IHP Systems](https://github.com/IHPSystems) packages - the intent is to change that going forward.

I'm happy to hear that! What kind of time frame did you have in mind for building up some documentation?

[noblock]

> > It is true that we have spent almost no effort on documentation of the [IHP Systems](https://github.com/IHPSystems) packages - the intent is to change that going forward.
> 
> I'm happy to hear that! What kind of time frame did you have in mind for building up some documentation?

It will of course be an ongoing process, but regarding ImageAnnotations and dependent packages:
* ONNXRuntimeImageAnnotators: I think documentation as of now is on par with code, and tests, so it should just be a natural requirement for each change going forward.
* FiftyOneImageAnnotations (#88970): Under-documented as of now, but also the very elaborate upstream [FiftyOne Documentation](https://docs.voxel51.com) applies - pretty much 1-1. It will not be a goal to re-do the FiftyOne documentation in its entirety. There should be documentation of common use cases in Julia - and documentation of the integration with the ImageAnnotations package. 
* ImageAnnotationsIO (#88272): Slightly under-documented - will add/improve documentation with each change going forward. It's also under-tested.

Regarding a timeline - it's a bit hard to say, as these packages are maintained partially within our day jobs @ IHP Systems, and partially (mostly, really) in my spare time. Tim's thread on Discourse on timelines in open source applies: https://discourse.julialang.org/t/why-open-source-timelines-roadmaps-dont-work/99518

These packages are however supporting our daily job @ IHP Systems and so will receive a significant effort wrt. correctness and features, but also wrt. documentation.

The practice @ IHP Systems has been for "self-documenting code" - as documentation often can get out of sync. It's of course much less of a problem in Julia with doctests, but yeah we're used to working with code **with** tests - *without* documentation. But the aim is to change that - while also highlighting (in house) the nice documentation features of the Julia ecosystem.

So no documentation updates tomorrow, but I hope the speediness of the README updates were an indication of the speed with which documentation will be added :-)

[noblock]

Alright‚Ä¶ I'll unblock my comments, and trust that you follow up with the documentation ;-)

[noblock]

> Alright‚Ä¶ I'll unblock my comments, and trust that you follow up with the documentation ;-)

Great! Thanks for reviewing and highlighting an area for improvement :-)

[noblock]
Considering package extension prospect‚Ä¶

I think the comments here blocked the merge.

Manual merge may be needed at this point. 

[noblock]

This pull request has been inactive for 30 days and will be automatically closed 7 days from now. If this pull request should not be closed, please either (1) fix the AutoMerge issues and re-trigger Registrator, which will automatically update the pull request, or (2) post a comment explaining why you would like this pull request to be manually merged. [noblock]

[noblock] @stemann https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/89020#issuecomment-1666838972 is blocking the merge. I just want to double check that this is intentional and that you no longer want to register this package
[noblock] @vchuravy I‚Äôm not sure the ‚Äúneeds manual merge‚Äù tag is accurate here, see https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/89020#issuecomment-1712720113

@goerz Yes, I will most likely try to go with the more generic approach suggested by @ashwani-rathee and filed in https://github.com/IHPSystems/ONNXRuntimeImageAnnotators.jl/issues/2 - and try to register under another name.

Feel free to close this.
@vchuravy Can you close this, to make sure nobody merges it by accident?

This pull request has been inactive for 30 days and will be automatically closed 7 days from now. If this pull request should not be closed, please either (1) fix the AutoMerge issues and re-trigger Registrator, which will automatically update the pull request, or (2) post a comment explaining why you would like this pull request to be manually merged. [noblock]
This pull request has been inactive for more than 30 days and has automatically been closed. Feel free to register your package or version again once you fix the AutoMerge issues. [noblock]
